Technical Assistance Report  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 40229 
Regional Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
February 2009 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Support for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation 
Financial Regulators Training Initiative

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  APEC   –  Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  FMM  –  Finance Ministers Meeting 
  FRTI  –  Financial Regulators Training Initiative 
  IOSCO  –  International Organization of Securities Commissions 
  SEACEN  –  South East Asian Central Banks

  US  –  United States 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional Capacity development technical assistance 
(R-CDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Finance 
Subsector  –  Finance sector development 
Themes  –  Economic growth, regional cooperation and integration,

NOTE 
 
                                   In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Head  J. W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Director  S. Madhur, OREI 
   
Team leader  L. Schou-Zibell, Senior Economist, OREI

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  May  1998,  the  Finance  Ministers’  Meeting  (FMM)  of  the  Asia-Pacific  Economic 
Cooperation  (APEC)1  endorsed  the  launching  of  the  APEC  Financial  Regulators  Training 
Initiative (FRTI) to strengthen training for national and regional financial regulators in Asia and 
the  Pacific.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  financially  supported  FRTI  training 
activities from the start and has been acting as the FRTI secretariat since 1998. Given the 
progress achieved under the FRTI and the continued need for financial regulation training in the 
region, the 15th APEC FMM on 5–6 November 2008 in Trujillo, Peru, extended the FRTI for 2 
more years and requested a continuation of ADB support. 
 
2.  This regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) is intended to provide ADB 
support for the APEC FRTI in the next 2 years under the APEC Finance Ministers’ Process. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Since the first APEC FMM in 1994 in Honolulu, the ADB President has been invited to 
these annual meetings and ADB staff have helped promote policy dialogue on (i) the setting of 
macroeconomic policies, (ii) the reform of financial market infrastructure for financial sector 
stability and restructuring, (iii) the strengthening of supervisory and regulatory frameworks for 
prudent and effective financial markets, and (iv) the development of the capital markets. ADB 
has also supported various capacity development efforts, including the APEC FRTI. ADB has 
assisted  the  forums  through  six  TA  projects2  involving  studies,  surveys,  workshops,  and 
capacity development seminars related to the policy agenda and initiatives of the APEC Finance 
Ministers' Process. 
 
4.  The Asian financial crisis that began in 1997 exposed structural weaknesses and flaws 
in the functioning of financial markets in the affected economies. A major cause of the crisis was 
the  inadequacy  of  financial  sector  regulation  and  supervision,  constrained  by  policy  and 
governance  issues,  as  well  as  low  capacity  among  banking  supervisors  and  securities 
regulators. Many APEC economies and ADB developing member countries (DMCs) have since 
committed themselves to implementing the core principles of banking supervision and securities 
regulation  developed  by  the  Bank  for  International  Settlements  and  the  International 
Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO). The current global financial market turmoil, 
which had its epicenter in the US subprime market in mid-2007, has been a reminder of the 
                                                 
1  The member economies of APEC are Australia; Brunei Darussalam; Canada; Chile; the People’s Republic of 
China; Hong Kong, China; Indonesia; Japan; the Republic of Korea; Malaysia; Mexico; New Zealand; Papua New 
Guinea; Peru; the Philippines; the Russian Federation; Singapore; Taipei,China; Thailand; the United States; and 
Viet Nam. 
2  ADB. 1996. Technical Assistance for New Initiatives on Infrastructure Financing and Regional Capital Market 
Development. Manila (TA 5708-REG, $600,000, approved 11 November); ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance for 
Collaborative Initiatives for Capital and Financial Market Development. Manila (TA 5763-REG, $400,000, approved 
22 December); ADB. 1999. Technical Assistance for APEC Growth Recovery Initiatives. Manila (TA 5847-REG, 
$2,150,000, approved 19 May); ADB. 2000. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building for Financial Regulation 
and Supervision. Manila (TA 5966-REG, $800,000, approved 27 December); ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance for 
Strengthening the Capacity of Financial Sector Regulations and Supervisors. Manila (TA 6148-REG, $480,000, 
approved 23 December); and ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Support for APEC Fiscal and Financial 
Initiatives. Manila (TA 6330-REG, $800.000, approved 31 July).

2        
importance of strong prudential standards, supervision, and regulation to the stability of financial 
systems. 
 
5.  Financial sector stability in Asia and the Pacific demands better-trained national and 
regional financial regulators. The aims of the FRTI are to (i) develop and provide broad-based 
training to junior and mid-level financial sector regulators and supervisors; (ii) strengthen the 
training  programs  for  bank  supervisors  and  securities  regulators;  and  (iii)  improve  the 
coordination of regional and international training programs. The APEC FRTI provides training 
to APEC member economies in Asia and the Pacific (most of which are also ADB DMCs), 
including smaller member countries that cannot provide the training themselves, and others with 
budget and other constraints on their training programs. 
 
6.  The first phase of the training (1998–2000) centered on improving the management of 
national training programs and program quality. The second phase (since 2001) is concerned 
with strengthening the conduct of regional and national training courses, developing training 
materials and distributing them to APEC member economies, and improving the coordination of 
regional and international training.  
 
7.  ADB serves as the secretariat of the APEC FRTI, and an advisory group3 guides and 
steers FRTI implementation. The chair of the advisory group has been rotated among the 
members  since  2004  to  increase  ownership.4   The  training  programs  are  held  at  ADB 
headquarters  as  well  as  in  host  institutions  throughout  the  region. Besides  the  secretariat 
activities, ADB funds the travel expenses of resource persons while host institutions sponsor 
social events. Participation in the training seminars is free of charge. Airfare, hotel, and other 
travel-related costs are borne by the institution nominating the participant. 
 
8.  The FRTI has separate programs for banking supervisors and for securities regulators.5 
Resource persons for the banking program come from the US Federal Reserve System, the 
Toronto Centre, and other institutions with considerable experience in banking supervision. 
Presenters and facilitators for the securities training program include experts from the US 
Securities and Exchange Commission, the Securities and Futures Commission of Hong Kong, 
the Securities Commission of Malaysia, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, the Australian 
Securities  and  Investments  Commission,  and  ADB.  The  South  East  Asian  Central  Banks 
(SEACEN) Research and Training Centre, the main regional training institution for banking 
supervisors in Asia, is a member of the advisory group. 
 
9.  In its 10 years of existence, the FRTI has strengthened the content and management of 
national training programs and developed regional programs. Training programs based on the 
core curricula developed under the initiative have been put in place or upgraded. FRTI training 
resources  are  also  used  in  nationally  led  training  programs.  A  website 
(www.adb.org/Projects/APEC)  has  been  created  to  facilitate  information  dissemination  and 
                                                 
3  The members of the advisory group are from APEC member economies, as follows: (i) for bank supervision, 
Australia; Brunei Darussalam; the People’s Republic of China; Hong Kong, China; Indonesia; the Republic of 
Korea; Malaysia; the Philippines, Singapore; the South East Asian Central Banks (SEACEN); Taipei,China; 
Thailand; the United States; and Viet Nam; and (ii) for securities supervision, Australia; the People’s Republic of 
China; Hong Kong, China; Indonesia; the Republic of Korea; Malaysia; New Zealand; the Philippines, Singapore; 
Taipei,China; Thailand; the United States; and Viet Nam. 
4  The organization structure of APEC FRTI can be found on the ADB project website for the APEC Financial 
Regulators Training Initiative. http://www.adb.org/Projects/APEC/structure.asp 
5  The World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, and other donors have also provided capacity development TA 
to policy makers and regulatory bodies in the region through the Financial Sector Reform and Strengthening 
(FIRST) initiative.

3
exchange. The unique networking possibilities among staff and resource persons have been 
particularly welcomed by the various regulatory and supervisory bodies in the region. The APEC 
member economies have also derived substantive ancillary benefits from the country case 
studies and the sharing of individual country experiences. Since 2001, the FRTI has trained 
more than 2,300 participants in 37 banking supervision seminars (9 national, 28 regional) and 
26 securities regulation seminars (4 national, 22 regional). Non-APEC economies have been 
participating more and more in the training.  
 
10.  Each  training  program  is  evaluated  by  seminar  participants  and  the  FRTI  itself  is 
evaluated yearly by advisory group members through a survey. Evaluation and survey results 
are compiled yearly and discussed at the annual meeting of advisory group members usually 
held in the third quarter. The training programs for the following year are also decided on at this 
meeting. The annual evaluation surveys assess the quality and effectiveness of seminars and of 
the approaches and methods used. The results of the assessment provide a basis for the 
design of training programs and enable advisory group members to suggest specific ways in 
which the programs can be further strengthened and improved to meet training needs. The 
evaluations include a summary measure of the value of each seminar based on the participants’ 
assessment  of  the  usefulness  of  the  knowledge  and  skills  gained  in  their  current  work 
assignments, and their general satisfaction with the course. The results of the evaluation survey 
among  advisory  group  members  in  2008  indicated  a  high  degree  of  satisfaction  with  the 
programs and general attainment of the overall objectives. FRTI programs are quite distinct 
from university programs: they are directed at working-level staff6 and draw heavily on the 
expertise of incumbent regulators in addressing specialized and current financial issues.  
 
11.  The  continued  implementation  of  the  FRTI  was  supported  by  the  advisory  group 
members at their last annual meeting in September 2008, in acknowledgment of the constant 
need for regional training programs, and from the APEC finance ministers at their last meeting 
in Peru. Regional training programs promote closer coordination of regulatory approaches, 
particularly  on  topics  that  are  relatively  new.  The  possibility  of  offering  short  but  in-depth 
seminars (2–3 days) tailored to the specific needs of member economies will also be explored. 
These seminars would increase awareness and deepen understanding of policy issues and 
suggested ways of dealing with them. While FRTI courses are designed primarily for the APEC 
economies and ADB member countries in the region, the advisory group members agreed not 
to limit participation in view of the positive effects of diversity—easier international comparisons 
of practices, enriched group work and discussions, and expanded networks.  
 
12.  APEC has helped the FRTI solicit resource speakers from more advanced economies. 
Their participation, however, depends on the availability of senior staff of regulatory agencies, a 
factor that could limit the effectiveness of the training. For the follow-up regional TA, resource 
speakers from ADB, but not necessarily APEC, member economies may be invited to share 
their views and knowledge of best practices. Advisory group members support such a move. 
International organizations like IOSCO and SEACEN may also be invited to conduct future 
seminars. Closer collaboration with these providers will be promoted. Links to their respective 
websites are available on the ADB project website. 
                                                 
6   Information on the FRTI training programs is available on the ADB project website for the APEC initiative: 
http://www.adb.org/Projects/APEC/banking.asp

4        
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The TA support for the FRTI is expected to improve compliance with international best 
practices in banking and securities supervision and regulation. As a result, financial sector 
regulators  and  supervisors  should  become  better  able  to  coordinate  and  monitor  financial 
institutions and systems and respond effectively to emerging issues.  
 
14.  The TA will support the implementation of ADB’s regional cooperation and integration 
strategy by contributing to monetary and financial cooperation and integration (the third strategic 
pillar). The TA is also in line with the key result areas of the Office of Regional Economic 
Integration  of  supporting  capacity  development  and  institutional  strengthening,  promoting 
regional  economic  policy  dialogue,  and  conducting  research  on  regional  cooperation  and 
integration. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will have three outputs:  
 
(i)  Output 1: Regular updating of financial market supervision and regulation 
knowledge in the region. The FRTI has made good progress in achieving its 
two original objectives: strengthening the content and management of national 
training programs, and developing regional programs for junior and mid-Ievel 
supervisors and regulators. The TA will continue to support the APEC FRTI for 2 
more years7 through training programs, conferences, and seminars as well as 
advisory group meetings; the upgrading of the APEC FRTI project website; and 
efforts to market the training programs. 
(ii)  Output 2: Up-to-date training of financial market supervisors and regulators 
by national training institutions. The TA will support the updating of course 
curricula  and  materials  by  financial  supervisory  authorities  and  regional 
institutions, and the continued building of a critical mass of potential trainers in 
the region through the training of selected officials. 
(iii)  Output 3: Independent evaluation to assess the impact of the FRTI. An 
independent evaluation of the FRTI will be conducted after 10 years of support to 
assess (a) its impact in improving the methodology, quality, and effectiveness of 
financial sector regulation and supervision; (b) its relevance as a mechanism for 
making financial sector regulators and supervisors better able to monitor and 
coordinate  financial  institutions  and  systems  and  to  respond  effectively  to 
emerging issues; (c) the extent to which it is relevant and complementary to 
training programs provided by other institutions; (d) the quality, accessibility, and 
application of its knowledge products, including its course materials and website; 
(e) the efficiency and effectiveness of its governance arrangements, including the 
membership  and  structure  of  the  advisory  group,  and  the  operation, 
administration, and performance of the APEC FRTI secretariat; and (f) options for 
sustaining an effective training initiative. 
                                                 
7  Extensions of the APEC FRTI are endorsed yearly by the APEC FMM. However, this TA proposes ADB support for 
the next 2 years, as strongly recommended by the APEC advisory group members.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000, to be financed with a grant from ADB’s TA 
funding  program  (TASF-IV).  This  amount  covers  the  remuneration  and  travel  expenses  of 
international and national consultants, the travel expenses of seminar and conference resource 
persons, the upgrading of training programs, and other miscellaneous expenses. Activities in 
non-ADB member countries and the procurement of resources from those countries (including 
the  participation  of  resource  persons  as  well  as  trainees)  are  not  covered.  The  TA  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the Executing Agency, and the Office of Regional Economic Integration will 
implement the TA, in close collaboration with the advisory group of the APEC FRTI.  
 
18.  The  TA  activities  will  be  implemented  with  the  help  of  international  and  national 
consultants. In support of APEC FRTI activities, the TA will fund (i) at least 16 training programs 
on  priority  topics  for  banking  and  securities  supervisors  and  regulators;  (ii)  at  least  two 
conferences or seminars where ideas on relevant topics in financial market supervision and 
regulation can be discussed and exchanged; (iii) two advisory group meetings to review the 
outcome of the training initiative and determine future APEC FRTI training needs; (iv) the 
upgrading of the APEC FRTI project website and intensified marketing of the training program; 
(v) the updating of course curricula and materials; and (vi) an independent evaluation of the 
impact of the APEC FRTI. Through discussions within a community of experts made possible by 
ADB’s active participation in this process, ADB staff can also learn new approaches to dealing 
with specific policy issues. These new ideas may be useful in ADB’s own policy dialogue with its 
DMCs and in DMC reform programs. Thus, the governance, finance, and trade divisions of the 
regional departments will be encouraged to participate as far as possible in the seminars, either 
directly or indirectly, by providing inputs and feedback on ADB’s contribution. 
 
19.  The  TA  will  require  about  13  person-months  of  international  consulting  services, 
24 person-months of national consulting services, and 12 person-months of resource persons’ 
participation. The TA will be implemented over 2 years, from April 2009. Consultants and 
resource  persons  will  be  hired  individually  according  to  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The scope of work and outline terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. Disbursements under the TA will conform to 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.8
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis for 
the Support for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Financial Regulators Training Initiative, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  Collaborative initiatives mandated by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) 
Finance Ministers’ Process may require some activities other than those identified in these 
outline terms of reference. In that case the terms of reference will be suitably modified to enable 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to fulfill its commitments and responsibilities. 
A.   Financial Sector Supervision Training Expert (international, 9 person-months) 
2.  The expert will 
 
(i)  manage the structure of the advisory group of the APEC Financial Regulators 
Training Initiative (FRTI) by 
(a)  preparing and facilitating advisory group meetings; 
(b)  conducting  and  analyzing  regular  surveys  on  the  status  of  national 
training efforts and emerging training needs; 
(c)  coordinating with other regional and global training providers;  
(d)  collecting  information  on  regional  training  resources,  materials,  and 
events,  and  circulating  the  information  through  ADB’s  external  APEC 
website and other means; and 
(e)  reviewing and advising on the development of the project website; 
(ii)  prepare progress reports on the FRTI for the APEC Finance Ministers’ Process;  
(iii)  organize and facilitate regional training seminars under the FRTI for banking and 
securities regulators;  
(iv)  organize the transfer of training programs and products developed under the 
FRTI to regional and national training institutions; 
(v)  coordinate with regulatory agencies in developed APEC economies regarding the 
provision of instructors and, with the host country, finalize training programs, act 
as facilitator in seminars, and prepare concise evaluation reports; and 
(vi)  prepare guidelines for the development of case studies for training (hypothetical 
as well as based on actual cases). 
B.   Resource Persons for Financial Regulatory Training Programs (international, 12 
person-months)1  
3.  The resource persons will 
 
(i)  participate in the training courses and seminars; 
(ii)   prepare and make presentations during the training courses and seminars (on 
topics to be determined in discussions with ADB), and 
(iii)   prepare case studies and facilitate case-study discussions. 
C.  Independent Evaluator (international, 2 person-months) 
4.  An international consultant will be hired to evaluate independently the effectiveness of 
the FRTI in improving the capacity of financial sector regulators and supervisors to monitor and 
coordinate financial institutions and systems and to respond effectively to emerging issues. 
                                                 
1 The effective delivery of each training program requires the participation of an average of three resource persons.

10  Appendix 3 
 
Options for sustaining an effective training initiative will be recommended. This consultant will 
assess 
 
(i)  the impact of the FRTI in improving the methods and quality of regulation and 
supervision  in  the  financial  sector,  and  the  effectiveness  of  these  methods  in 
developing, maintaining, and monitoring stable and efficient financial institutions and 
systems as well as in promoting sustainable economic growth;  
(ii)  the relevance of the FRTI as a mechanism for making financial sector regulators and 
supervisors better able to monitor and coordinate financial institutions and systems 
and to respond effectively to emerging issues; 
(iii)  the extent to which the FRTI is relevant and complementary to training programs 
provided by other institutions; 
(iv)  the quality, accessibility, and application of FRTI knowledge products, including the 
course materials and website; and 
(v)  the efficiency and effectiveness of FRTI governance arrangements including (a) the 
membership  and  structure  of  the  advisory  group;  and  (b)  the  operation, 
administration, and performance of the secretariat. 
D.   Editor (international, 2 person-months)   
5.  The expert will  
 
(i)  edit FRTI website pages; and 
(ii)  edit FRTI-related documents for dissemination. 
E.  Project Specialist (national, 12 person-months) 
6.  The project specialist will provide research, technical, and administrative support for 
activities to be implemented under the TA. The specialist will 
 
(i)  assist  in  the  preparation  of  briefing  papers  and  presentation  materials  for 
seminars, conferences, and other related TA events; 
(ii)  prepare and update progress reports, including budget summaries; 
(iii)  coordinate  with  training  experts  to  ensure  that  activities  are  implemented 
according  to  pertinent  ADB  rules  and  guidelines  on  various  aspects  of 
management and control; 
(iv)  assist in organizing regional meetings and seminars; 
(v)  maintain and upgrade the project website to improve network accessibility and 
usefulness among financial regulators, and coordinate with the ADB Department 
of External Relations on postings; 
(vi)  search the Internet for information on training resources, materials, and events 
related to the TA activities that are available from other regional and global 
training providers; and 
(vii)  prepare and maintain a database of trainees and resource persons. 
F.  Coordinating Expert (national, 12 person-months) 
7.   The coordinating expert will act as the focal person to ensure smooth coordination and 
flow of communication among members of the advisory group, banking and securities regulators, 
seminar resource persons, and participants. The coordinating expert will

(iii)  coordinate  with  resource  persons  and  participants  regarding  their  hiring  and 
participation in seminars; and
